articles.headline: Disease Threatens Japan’s Beef Trade
articles.snippet: Japan is trying to control its worst outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in a century.
articles.abstract: Japan is trying to control its worst outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in a century.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIYAZAKI, Japan  It is a calamity for this quiet cattle community. A prized black calf born last fall will soon be killed, part of the mass destruction of livestock in Japan’s battle against its worst foot-and-mouth disease outbreak in at least a century.

articles.headline: Obama Takes a Hard Line Against Leaks to Press
articles.snippet: In 17 months in office, President Obama has already outdone every previous president in pursuing leak prosecutions.
articles.abstract: In 17 months in office, President Obama has already outdone every previous president in pursuing leak prosecutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Hired in 2001 by the National Security Agency to help it catch up with the e-mail and cellphone revolution, Thomas A. Drake became convinced that the government’s eavesdroppers were squandering hundreds of millions of dollars on failed programs while ignoring a promising alternative.

articles.headline: Flash Floods Sweep Through Arkansas Camps
articles.snippet: At least 16 people were killed and dozens more were unaccounted for after flash floods swept through campgrounds in Arkansas on Friday, officials said.
articles.abstract: At least 16 people were killed and dozens more were unaccounted for after flash floods swept through campgrounds in Arkansas on Friday, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: LODI, Ark.  At least 16 people were killed and dozens more were unaccounted for after flash floods raged through campgrounds in western Arkansas early Friday morning.
articles.byline: By Evin Demirel and Erik Eckholm

articles.headline: Punishing BP Is Harder Than Boycotting Stations
articles.snippet: Telling oil companies that you’re not going to take it anymore requires a change in lifestyle.
articles.abstract: Telling oil companies that you’re not going to take it anymore requires a change in lifestyle.
articles.lead_paragraph: With each day that oil fouls the Gulf of Mexico, more drivers are weighing a choice at intersections across the United States: if BP is on the left and some other station is on the right, is filling up at BP an endorsement of the company’s conduct?

articles.headline: Karzai Is Said to Doubt West Can Defeat Taliban
articles.snippet: The Afghan president has been pressing to strike his own deal with the Taliban and Pakistan because he has lost confidence that the United States and NATO will win, officials said.
articles.abstract: The Afghan president has been pressing to strike his own deal with the Taliban and Pakistan because he has lost confidence that the United States and NATO will win, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two senior Afghan officials were showing President Hamid Karzai the evidence of the spectacular rocket attack on a nationwide peace conference earlier this month when Mr. Karzai told them that he believed the Taliban were not responsible.

articles.headline: Wake-Up Time for a Dream
articles.snippet: Despite the financial crisis, few are willing to address a key factor behind it: the concept of homeownership for all.
articles.abstract: Despite the financial crisis, few are willing to address a key factor behind it: the concept of homeownership for all.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sheila Bair, the chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, began her week with a bit of honest heresy, the kind that only she, among all the bank regulators, seems willing to utter in the wake of the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Credit Unions Begin to Promote Their Strengths
articles.snippet: With time-worn routines, credit unions avoided the traps of the big banks, but until now, very few let it be known.
articles.abstract: With time-worn routines, credit unions avoided the traps of the big banks, but until now, very few let it be known.
articles.lead_paragraph: Credit unions have a reputation for being rather dull and conservative, and for decades, America’s First Federal Credit Union in Birmingham, Ala., was no exception.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Will Last Century’s Styles Open Today’s Wallets?
articles.snippet: Clothing brands are betting hard-pressed consumers will prefer the comfort of goods from the past, when times weren’t so tough.
articles.abstract: Clothing brands are betting hard-pressed consumers will prefer the comfort of goods from the past, when times weren’t so tough.
articles.lead_paragraph: For some clothing brands, the summer of 2010 looks a lot like the summer of 1910, and 1949, and 1957  basically, any time but now.

articles.headline: Craft Shop Family Buys Up Ancient Bibles for Museum
articles.snippet: The evangelical Christian family that owns the Hobby Lobby chain is spending millions to amass a treasure trove of rare ancient Bibles and other religious artifacts.
articles.abstract: The evangelical Christian family that owns the Hobby Lobby chain is spending millions to amass a treasure trove of rare ancient Bibles and other religious artifacts.
articles.lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY  At least one example of the printed word is in great demand even in the digital age: ancient Bibles.

articles.headline: Uncertainty Restores Glitter to an Old Refuge, Gold
articles.snippet: It was once a favorite of the fringe, but now even well-known investors are buying gold amid rising concerns about currencies, bailouts and debts.
articles.abstract: It was once a favorite of the fringe, but now even well-known investors are buying gold amid rising concerns about currencies, bailouts and debts.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the resurgent passion of the doomsday crowd, a bet that everything will go wrong. No matter what has you worried, they say, the answer is gold.

articles.headline: Florida Skips Offshore Oil Binge but Still Pays
articles.snippet: With oil continuing to gush from a well off Louisiana, Florida has grown angrier at its oil-friendly neighbors.
articles.abstract: With oil continuing to gush from a well off Louisiana, Florida has grown angrier at its oil-friendly neighbors.
articles.lead_paragraph: KEY LARGO, Fla.  When rigs first started drilling for oil off Louisiana’s coast in the 1940s, Floridians scanned their shoreline, with its resorts and talcum-white beaches, and said, No thanks. Go ahead and drill, they told other Gulf Coast states; we’ll stick with tourism.

articles.headline: Finally, Borrowers Score Points
articles.snippet: The new scrutiny of mortgage foreclosure practices, like a $108 million fine extracted from Bank of America last week, is long overdue.
articles.abstract: The new scrutiny of mortgage foreclosure practices, like a $108 million fine extracted from Bank of America last week, is long overdue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHILE the wheels of justice have turned very slowly in the years since our nation’s financiers and regulators nearly cratered our economy, the Federal Trade Commission’s settlement last Monday with Countrywide Home Loans suggests that they haven’t entirely ground to a halt.

articles.headline: Merely Human? That’s So Yesterday
articles.snippet: The Singularity movement sees a time when human beings and machines will merge and overcome illness and perhaps death.
articles.abstract: The Singularity movement sees a time when human beings and machines will merge and overcome illness and perhaps death.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.

articles.headline: As Afghan Fighting Expands, U.S. Medics Plunge In
articles.snippet: Nearly nine years into the war, the pace for air crews that retrieve the wounded has become pitched.
articles.abstract: Nearly nine years into the war, the pace for air crews that retrieve the wounded has become pitched.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARJA, Afghanistan  The Marine had been shot in the skull. He was up ahead, at the edge of a field, where the rest of his patrol was fighting. A Black Hawk medevac helicopter flew above treetops toward him, banked and hovered dangerously before landing nearby.

articles.headline: U.S. Intelligence Puts New Focus on Afghan Graft
articles.snippet: Military officers are looking for insights on how to combat perversion of authority by Afghan power brokers.
articles.abstract: Military officers are looking for insights on how to combat perversion of authority by Afghan power brokers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The military’s intelligence network in Afghanistan, designed for identifying and tracking terrorists and insurgents, is increasingly focused on uncovering corruption that is rampant across Afghanistan’s government, security forces and contractors, according to senior American officials.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Ethnic Rioting Ravages Kyrgyzstan
articles.snippet: Much of Osh was in ruins after rioting that appeared to be aimed at ethnic Uzbeks; the official death toll in southern Kyrgyzstan rose to more than 100.
articles.abstract: Much of Osh was in ruins after rioting that appeared to be aimed at ethnic Uzbeks; the official death toll in southern Kyrgyzstan rose to more than 100.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  After three days of ethnic rioting that spread across the south of this strategically important Central Asian nation, many streets in this city lay in smoldering ruins on Sunday night.

articles.headline: Obama Plans First Oval Office Speech to Put Pressure on BP
articles.snippet: The speech is part of a week of activities intended to convey presidential command of a crisis that continues to test both the U.S. and the company.
articles.abstract: The speech is part of a week of activities intended to convey presidential command of a crisis that continues to test both the U.S. and the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Searching for a way to satisfy both the United States government and its own shareholders, the board of BP was examining three options for what to do with its next dividend, a person with direct knowledge of the board’s discussions said Monday.

articles.headline: A Disaster, Privately Managed
articles.snippet: Weeks into the oil spill, public information seems to be controlled by BP, in whole or in part.
articles.abstract: Weeks into the oil spill, public information seems to be controlled by BP, in whole or in part.
articles.lead_paragraph: The three journalists crept along in a boat captained by James Ledet in a bayou near Golden Meadow, La., one early afternoon. We were all looking for the same thing as we traversed narrow stretches of water framed by swamp grass, in a landscape dotted with docked shrimp boats and old oil rigs.

articles.headline: Once Just a Site With Funny Cat Pictures, and Now a Web Empire
articles.snippet: Traffic to the I Can Has Cheezburger blog has ballooned over the last three years, encouraging its owner to host 53 sites propelled by reader submissions.
articles.abstract: Traffic to the I Can Has Cheezburger blog has ballooned over the last three years, encouraging its owner to host 53 sites propelled by reader submissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE  Three years ago Ben Huh visited a blog devoted to silly cat pictures  and saw vast potential.

articles.headline: U.S. Drops Inspector of Food in China
articles.snippet: The U.S. has barred a leading inspector of organic food from China amid questions over its practices.
articles.abstract: The U.S. has barred a leading inspector of organic food from China amid questions over its practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Organic food from China, like tea and frozen broccoli, has increasingly found its way onto American store shelves, typically emblazoned with the green “U.S.D.A. organic” seal also found on food grown in this country.
articles.byline: By William Neuman and David Barboza

articles.headline: Hollywood Hopes ‘Toy Story 3’ Can Spur Summer Sales
articles.snippet: After a disappointing Memorial Day weekend, Hollywood is still waiting for hit movies to energize ticket sales and box office receipts.
articles.abstract: After a disappointing Memorial Day weekend, Hollywood is still waiting for hit movies to energize ticket sales and box office receipts.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Save us, Buzz Lightyear.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: In China, Unlikely Labor Leader Just Wanted a Middle-Class Life
articles.snippet: A 23-year-old moved nearly 500 miles to work at a Honda plant, only to find the wages inadequate. He took the bold step of organizing a strike.
articles.abstract: A 23-year-old moved nearly 500 miles to work at a Honda plant, only to find the wages inadequate. He took the bold step of organizing a strike.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Tan Guocheng is hardly a self-styled labor leader. Age 23 and introverted, he grew up among rice paddies and orange groves far from China’s big factory towns.

articles.headline: U.S. Identifies Vast Mineral Riches in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The nearly $1 trillion in untapped deposits are enough to fundamentally alter the Afghan economy and perhaps the Afghan war itself, officials said.
articles.abstract: The nearly $1 trillion in untapped deposits are enough to fundamentally alter the Afghan economy and perhaps the Afghan war itself, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States has discovered nearly $1 trillion in untapped mineral deposits in Afghanistan, far beyond any previously known reserves and enough to fundamentally alter the Afghan economy and perhaps the Afghan war itself, according to senior American government officials.

articles.headline: MTV Serves as Model for AOL Site
articles.snippet: The site, Cambio, is being billed as a next-generation video network, where entertainers can connect with their fans.
articles.abstract: The site, Cambio, is being billed as a next-generation video network, where entertainers can connect with their fans.
articles.lead_paragraph: The next time the Jonas Brothers release an album or announce a tour, they can skip “Entertainment Tonight” and YouTube and go straight to Cambio.

articles.headline: Children Carry Guns for a U.S. Ally, Somalia
articles.snippet: The Somali government is fielding hundreds of child soldiers, some as young as 9, according to rights groups and the U.N.
articles.abstract: The Somali government is fielding hundreds of child soldiers, some as young as 9, according to rights groups and the U.N.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Awil Salah Osman prowls the streets of this shattered city, looking like so many other boys, with ripped-up clothes, thin limbs and eyes eager for attention and affection.

articles.headline: Russia Weighs Pleas to Step In as Uzbeks Flee Kyrgyzstan
articles.snippet: Both sides of the conflict between Uzbeks and Kyrgyz were calling on Russia to step in after four days of ethnic violence.
articles.abstract: Both sides of the conflict between Uzbeks and Kyrgyz were calling on Russia to step in after four days of ethnic violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSH, Kyrgyzstan — As four days of ethnic violence in southern Kyrgyzstan threatened to build into a major refugee crisis on Monday, both sides of the conflict were calling on Russia to step in, saying third-party peacekeepers were needed to defuse standoffs between Uzbeks and Kyrgyz.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Obama, Visiting Gulf, Tries to Lift Economy and Mood
articles.snippet: President Obama said that the federal government would push hard to make sure that the British oil  giant pays back lost income from the oil spill.
articles.abstract: President Obama said that the federal government would push hard to make sure that the British oil  giant pays back lost income from the oil spill.
articles.lead_paragraph: THEODORE, Ala.  President Obama on Monday stepped up his efforts to limit the economic fallout from the oil spill, announcing steps to assure consumers that seafood from the Gulf of Mexico is safe and promoting tourism in the region as BP, under pressure from the White House, agreed to accelerate the cleanup.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Henry Fountain
